author: WillPittenger
body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

Currently, when Get-ChildItem returns a file size, it's in bytes—even if the size is several terabytes.  bash lets users specify the `-h` switch to ls.  In Powershell, it's more complex as Get-ChildItem doesn't know anything about the data.  Adding the switch would cause the method to prefer human readable sizes.  The switch would look for a property named `Length` and replace that in the select with `LengthAsStr` (if that exists in the class) which would be assumed to be human readable.

The second step would be to arrange with the authors of `System.Io.FileInfo` and `System.Io.DirectoryInfo` to add `LengthAsStr`.

I considered saying that Get-ChildItem itself could attempt to convert the field, but `Length` might be in something other than bytes, say characters.
